content: Singaporean politician **Lee Yock Suan** ([Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 李玉全; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Lǐ Yùquán*; born 30 September 1946) is a Singaporean former politician. A member of the governing [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP), he served in the [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore) between 1987 and 2004, and was a [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) (MP) between 1980 and 2006. He is the father of [Desmond Lee](/wiki/Desmond_Lee_(Singaporean_politician)), the current [Minister for Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)). ## Career Lee worked at Singapore's [Economic Development Board](/wiki/Economic_Development_Board) from 1969 to 1980, initially as a projects officer before becoming Divisional Director (Industry). From 1980 to 1981, he served as Deputy Managing Director of the Petroleum Corporation of Singapore. ### Political career Lee was first elected to Parliament at the [1980 general election](/wiki/1980_Singaporean_general_election). He served as an MP representing the [Cheng San Single Member Constituency](/wiki/Cheng_San_Single_Member_Constituency) (1980–88), the [Cheng San Group Representation Constituency](/wiki/Cheng_San_Group_Representation_Constituency) (1988–2001) and the [East Coast Group Representation Constituency](/wiki/East_Coast_Group_Representation_Constituency) (2001–06). After serving as a [Minister of State](/wiki/Minister_of_State#Minor_government_ranks) at the [Ministry of National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)) and the [Ministry of Finance](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(Singapore)) from 1983 to 1984, Lee was made the Acting [Minister for Labour](/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore)) in 1985. He became a full member of the Cabinet in 1987, and served as the Minister for Labour (1987–91), [Minister for Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)) (1992–97), [Second Minister for Finance](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(Singapore)) (1997–98), [Minister for Trade and Industry](/wiki/Ministry_of_Trade_and_Industry_(Singapore)) (1997–99), [Minister for Information and the Arts](/wiki/Minister_for_Information,_Communications_and_the_Arts_(Singapore)) (1999–2001), [Minister for the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_and_Water_Resources) (1999–2001), [Second Minister for Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Singapore)) (2001–04) and [Minister in the Prime Minister's Office](/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_(Singapore)) (2001–04). Lee also served as the Deputy Chairman of the [People's Association](/wiki/People%27s_Association) from 1984 to 1991, and as Chairman of the [Singapore Labour Foundation](/wiki/Singapore_Labour_Foundation) from 1997 to 2002. Lee stepped down from the Cabinet in 2004. He remained an MP until 2006, before retiring from politics at the [2006 general election](/wiki/2006_Singaporean_general_election). ## Education Lee was educated at [Queenstown Secondary Technical School](/wiki/Queenstown_Secondary_School) and [Raffles Institution](/wiki/Raffles_Institution), before being awarded a [President's Scholarship](/wiki/President%27s_Scholar) to study at [Imperial College London](/wiki/Imperial_College_London), where he completed a [BSc (Hons)](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Science) degree in [chemical engineering](/wiki/Chemical_engineering). He subsequently completed a Diploma in Business Administration at the [University of Singapore](/wiki/University_of_Singapore). ## Personal life Lee is a [Hokkien Chinese](/wiki/Hoklo_people) and is married to Adeline Oh Choon Neo and has one son and one daughter. His son, [Desmond Lee](/wiki/Desmond_Lee_(Singaporean_politician)), is a politician who is currently a [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) for [West Coast GRC](/wiki/West_Coast_Group_Representation_Constituency) and Minister for Education.
